question: How do technical degrees prepare individuals for the real world and signal seriousness of purpose to employers?
contexts:
['•
Plus, technical degrees teach you how think like an engineer,
a scientist, an economist, or a mathematician — how to use
reason, logic, and data. This is incredibly useful in the real
world, which generally demands rigorous thinking on the
path to doing anything big.
•
Plus, technical degrees indicate seriousness of purpose to
future employers and partners. You get coded right up front
as someone who is intent on doing real things.
Graduating with a technical degree is like heading out into the real
108
The Pmarca Blog Archives']
ground_truth: Technical degrees prepare individuals for the real world by teaching them how to think like an engineer, scientist, economist, or mathematician. They learn to use reason, logic, and data, which are essential skills for rigorous thinking in real-world scenarios. Additionally, technical degrees signal seriousness of purpose to future employers and partners, indicating that the individual is intent on pursuing real-world applications and projects.

question: How can undergraduates gain real-world working experience before graduating?
contexts:
['undergrads to do some of the work, and being a staW member at
a campus computer lab or research lab.
And then aggressively pursue internship and co-op programs — to
get real-world working experience at companies in your Xeld,
before you even graduate. Target the best companies in your
Xeld, and go aaer the opportunities early and oaen.
If you do this right, by the time you graduate even with just an
undergrad degree, you can have a year and a half of real work-
ing experience at high-quality companies plus another four

110']
ground_truth: Undergraduates can gain real-world working experience before graduating by doing some of the work themselves, being a staff member at a campus computer lab or research lab, and aggressively pursuing internship and co-op programs to work at companies in their field. By targeting the best companies early and often, undergraduates can accumulate a year and a half of real work experience at high-quality companies along with four years of practical experience from on-campus jobs by the time they graduate.

question: How are people abandoning older services like newspapers, magazines, television, movie theaters, and print catalogs in favor of online platforms?
contexts:
['billion people online now. That is a very large market — a lot
of people, spending a lot of time, buying a lot of things, in
totally new ways at the same time as they are abandoning older
services like newspapers, magazines, television, movie theaters,
and print catalogs.
So, my view is that to call a bubble, you have to Xnd evidence of
it outside of the mainstream of the kinds of Internet businesses
that are being built, sold, and run in 2007.
In closing, I’d be the last person to say that I never roll my eyes
at the next startup that’s doing online wiki-based popularity-']
ground_truth: People are abandoning older services like newspapers, magazines, television, movie theaters, and print catalogs in favor of online platforms due to the large market of billions of people online, spending a lot of time and buying things in new ways. This shift is evident in the decline of traditional media consumption and the rise of online businesses in 2007.

question: How can a startup ensure that they generate more revenue from a customer than it costs in sales and marketing expenses to acquire that customer?
contexts:
['sharp, because without that, you probably won’t be able to stand
out from the noise.
Then, model out your customer acquisition economics in detail
and make sure that you can show how you’ll get more revenue
from a customer than it will cost in sales and marketing expense
to acquire that customer. This is a common problem for star-
tups pursuing the small business market, for example.
If it turns out you need a lot of money in absolute terms for
marketing, look for alternate approaches — perhaps guerilla
marketing, or some form of virality.']
ground_truth: Modeling out customer acquisition economics in detail is crucial for startups to ensure that they generate more revenue from a customer than it costs in sales and marketing expenses to acquire that customer. By demonstrating a clear strategy for acquiring customers at a cost lower than the revenue they bring in, startups can address this common challenge, especially when targeting the small business market.

question: What is the potential consequence of the funding window not being open when a company needs more money?
contexts:
['Here’s why you shouldn’t do that:
What are the consequences of not raising enough money?
Not raising enough money risks the survival of your company,
for the following reasons:
First, you may have — and probably will have — unanticipated
setbacks within your business.
Maybe a new product release slips, or you have unexpected
quality issues, or one of your major customers goes bankrupt, or
a challenging new competitor emerges, or you get sued by a big
company for patent infringement, or you lose a key engineer.
Second, the funding window may not be open when you need
more money.']
ground_truth: The potential consequence of the funding window not being open when a company needs more money is that the survival of the company is at risk. This is because without access to additional funding, the company may face unanticipated setbacks within the business, such as delays in product releases, unexpected quality issues, loss of major customers, emergence of new competitors, legal challenges, or key personnel departures. Additionally, if the funding window is closed when more money is needed, the company may struggle to secure the necessary resources for continued operations and growth.
metadata: [{'source': 'https://d1lamhf6l6yk6d.cloudfront.net/uploads/2021/08/The-pmarca-Blog-Archives.pdf', 'file_path': 'https://d1lamhf6l6yk6d.cloudfront.net/uploads/2021/08/The-pmarca-Blog-Archives.pdf', 'page': 47, 'total_pages': 195, 'format': 'PDF 1.3', 'title': 'The Pmarca Blog Archives', 'author': '', 'subject': '', 'keywords': '', 'creator': '', 'producer': 'Mac OS X 10.10 Quartz PDFContext', 'creationDate': "D:20150110020418Z00'00'", 'modDate': "D:20150110020418Z00'00'", 'trapped': ''}]

ground_truth: Combining a useful graduate degree with a substantive undergraduate degree can make you a "double threat" in the workforce by providing you with a strong technical foundation and practical skills. This combination enhances your ability to contribute in a high-impact way and increases your value to potential employers.

question: What are the key areas to focus on when hiring the best people for a startup?
contexts:
["How to hire the best people you've
ever worked with
There are many aspects to hiring great people, and various peo-
ple smarter than me have written extensively on the topic.
So I’m not going to try to be comprehensive.
But I am going to relay some lessons learned through hard
experience on how to hire the best people you’ve ever worked
with — particularly for a startup.
I’m going to cover two key areas in this post:
•
Criteria: what to value when evaluating candidates.
•
And process: how to actually run the hiring process, and if
necessary the aaermath of making a mistake.
Criteria 7rst"]
ground_truth: The key areas to focus on when hiring the best people for a startup are criteria and process. Criteria involve what to value when evaluating candidates, while process entails how to run the hiring process and handle any aftermath of making a mistake.

question: How does a founder being the CEO in a startup affect relationships and decision-making?
contexts:
['sonal relationships within the group — so the desire to be liked
is stronger, and the perceived risk from making decisions that
people won’t like is higher.
A speciXc form of this dynamic in a startup is when you have
multiple founders, of whom one is the CEO. The founder who
is the CEO inevitably discovers that it becomes very hard to stay
close personal friends with the other founders. As they say, it’s
lonely at the top — if you’re doing your job right.
The Psychology of Entrepreneurial Misjudgment: Biases 1-6
147', 'ing to be liked can be a major impediment to entrepreneurial
success due to at least two major reasons.
First, an entrepreneur, like any CEO, has to make tough deci-
sions about what her company will do, and those decisions will
oaen run counter to the preferences of her employees. You
don’t have to be involved in that many startups to Xnd one
where the entrepreneur knows she needs to make a tough deci-
sion — such as change strategy, or cancel a Yawed project — but
can’t quite do it because employees won’t like it. Of course this
always backXres: employees also don’t like leaders who don’t']
ground_truth: When a founder is the CEO in a startup, it becomes challenging to maintain close personal relationships with other founders. The dynamic shifts as the CEO has to make tough decisions that may not align with the preferences of other founders, leading to potential strains in personal relationships. This can create a sense of loneliness at the top, as the CEO must prioritize the success of the company over personal friendships. Additionally, the desire to be liked can hinder entrepreneurial success, as tough decisions may need to be made that are not always popular among employees.

question: How to achieve inbox zero and enhance productivity with a specific email strategy?
contexts:
['When you do process email, do it like this
First, always Hnish each of your two daily email sessions with a
completely empty inbox.
I don’t know about you, but when I know I have emails in my
inbox that haven’t been dealt with, I Xnd it hard to concentrate
on other things.
The urge to go back to my email is nearly overpowering.
(I am apparently seriously addicted to endorphins.)
Second, when doing email, either answer or Hle every single
message until you get to that empty inbox state of grace.
Not keeping a schedule helps here, a lot, if you can pull it oW —', 'Only doing email twice a day will make you far more productive
for the rest of the day.
The problem with email is that getting an email triggers that
same endorphin hit I mentioned above — the one that a mouse
gets when he bonks on the button in the cage and gets a food
pellet.
Responding to an email triggers that same hit.
The pleasure chemical hits your neocortex and you go “ahhh”
inside and feel like you’ve done something.
So you sit and work with your mail client open and you inter-
rupt your work every time an email comes in and you answer it']
ground_truth: When processing email, it is recommended to finish each of the two daily email sessions with an empty inbox. This helps in maintaining focus and productivity. Additionally, it is advised to either respond or file away every single message until achieving an empty inbox. Not having a fixed schedule for checking emails can be beneficial, as limiting email checking to twice a day can significantly increase productivity. The issue with email is that receiving and responding to emails triggers a pleasure response similar to a mouse receiving a food pellet, leading to a distraction from other tasks.

question: What's the purpose of temporary Action subfolders in email organization and their interaction with Vault and Pending folders?

ing a schedule in 2007, I can’t commit to that.”

jects or pressing issues go into temporary subfolders of a
folder called Action.
You should only have Action subfolders for the things that really
matter, right now.
Those subfolders then get used, and the messages in them
processed, when you are working on their respective projects in
the normal course of your day.
Fourth, aside from those temporary Action subfolders, only', 'Every once in a while, sweep through your Action subfolders
and dump any of them that you can into Vault.
(And do the same thing for messages in your Pending folder —
most of the things in there you will never look at again. Actually,
same is true for Review.)
That’s it.
You can get away with this because modern email clients are so
good at search (well, most of them — and you can always move

lots of diWerent folders.
Obviously you may need some additional permanent folders']

question: How do senior staff influence startup team success in terms of team caliber, product quality, and market conditions?
contexts:
['Let’s start by deXning terms.
The caliber of a startup team
team can be deXned as the suitability of
the CEO, senior staW, engineers, and other key staW relative to
the opportunity in front of them.
You look at a startup and ask, will this team be able to optimally
execute against their opportunity? I focus on eWectiveness as
opposed to experience, since the history of the tech industry is
full of highly successful startups that were staWed primarily by
people who had never “done it before”.
The quality of a startup’s pr
product
oduct can be deXned as how impres-', 'caliber and quality for the three core elements of each startup
— team, product, and market.
At any given startup, the team will range from outstanding to
remarkably Yawed; the product will range from a masterpiece
of engineering to barely functional; and the market will range
from booming to comatose.
And so you start to wonder — what correlates the most to suc-
cess — team, product, or market? Or, more bluntly, what causes
success? And, for those of us who are students of startup failure
— what’s most dangerous: a bad team, a weak product, or a
poor market?']

question: What are signs of product/market fit issues like word of mouth, customer value, and sales cycle length?
contexts:
['that can satisfy that market.
You can always feel when product/market Ft isn’t happening. The
customers aren’t quite getting value out of the product, word
of mouth isn’t spreading, usage isn’t growing that fast, press
reviews are kind of “blah”, the sales cycle takes too long, and lots
of deals never close.
And you can always feel product/market Ft when it’s happening. The
customers are buying the product just as fast as you can make it
— or usage is growing just as fast as you can add more servers.
Money from customers is piling up in your company checking']
ground_truth: Signs of product/market fit issues include customers not getting value from the product, word of mouth not spreading, slow growth in usage, lackluster press reviews, lengthy sales cycles, and deals not closing.

question: What benefits do technical degrees provide for preparing individuals for real-world challenges and impressing potential employers?
contexts:
['because all the jobs are going to India and China is silliness;
ignore it.
Hard science degrees — physics, chemistry — also clearly qual-
ify, as do mathematics and economics.
Why do I take this stance?
•
Technical degrees teach you how to do something diZcult
and useful that matters in the real world. Even if you don’t
end up actually doing what the degree teaches you how to do,
going through the experience of learning how to do it will
help you go through other serious learning experiences in
your career. Complexity and diZculty will not faze you.
•', '•
Plus, technical degrees teach you how think like an engineer,
a scientist, an economist, or a mathematician — how to use
reason, logic, and data. This is incredibly useful in the real
world, which generally demands rigorous thinking on the
path to doing anything big.
•
Plus, technical degrees indicate seriousness of purpose to
future employers and partners. You get coded right up front
as someone who is intent on doing real things.
Graduating with a technical degree is like heading out into the real
108
The Pmarca Blog Archives']
ground_truth: Technical degrees provide individuals with the skills to tackle difficult and practical tasks that are relevant in the real world. Even if the specific skills learned are not directly applied, the experience of learning them prepares individuals for future challenges. Additionally, technical degrees teach individuals how to think like engineers, scientists, economists, or mathematicians, emphasizing reason, logic, and data analysis. This skill set is highly valuable in a world that requires critical thinking for significant accomplishments. Furthermore, technical degrees signal to employers and partners a dedication to tangible achievements and problem-solving. Graduating with a technical degree demonstrates a commitment to real-world applications and challenges.

question: What advice does Scott Adams offer on public speaking and communication skills in the workplace, and how can it give an advantage over those with just one skill?
contexts:
['First, communication.
Back to Scott Adams:
I always advise young people to become good public speakers (top
25%). Anyone can do it with practice. If you add that talent to any
other, suddenly you’re the boss of the people who have only one
skill…
At least one of the skills in your mixture should involve communi-
cation, either written or verbal.
The great thing about communication is that most people are
terrible at it, because they never take it seriously as a skill to
develop.
This is particularly true of engineers and technical people, who']
ground_truth: Scott Adams advises young people to become good public speakers, as it can be achieved with practice and can give them an advantage over those with just one skill. By combining public speaking with another skill, individuals can become leaders in their field. Communication, whether written or verbal, is a crucial skill that many people overlook but can greatly benefit from developing.
